title.narrative: PPDP Inclusive Growth through Decent Work in the Great Rift Valley
PPDP Inclusive Growth through Decent Work in the Great Rift Valley

description.narrative:
Det privata företaget Akiira Geothermal Ltd håller på att etablerar ett geotermiskt kraftverk i den södra regionen av Rift Valley nära Naivasha, i Kenya. Den stundande produktionen av förnybar energi förväntas bidra till Kenyas växande ekonomi. För att de angränsande pastorala samhällena också skall gynnas av den ekonomiska tillväxen, måste medvetna och proaktiva åtgärder vidtas. Akiira är fast besluten att deras investering i regionen skall har en positiv påverkan på de närliggande samhällena vad gäller lokalt deltagande och skapande av arbetstillfällen under byggnads- och driftsfasen. För närvarande är det svårt för Akiira att anställa lokal arbetskraft, för annat än enklare jobb såsom chaufförer, vakter etcetera, på grund av bristande utbildning och andra färdigheter.
Med anledning av diskrepansen mellan den privata sektorns behov av anställningsbar arbetskraft och den lokala befolkningens kunskaper och färdigheter, har Akiira Geothermal Ltd och Sida, representerad av den svenska ambassaden i Nairobi, initierat ett partnerskap för att adressera några av de utvecklingsutmaningar som finns i regionen, såsom fattigdom, utslagenhet, brist på anställningsbarhet, ojämlikhet mellan könen och brist på grundläggande rättigheter till offentliga samhällstjänster. Modellen för partnerskapet är en så kallat Public Private Development Partnership (PPDP) med International Labour Organisation (ILO) som samordnare, genomförare och avtalspart för programmet. Forum Syd kommer även att ha en nyckelroll i delar av genomförandet av programmet. Ett större antal partners kommer även att delta och bidra till de gemensamt uppsatta målen för partnerskapet. Närmast involverade parter för PPDPn är Akiira Ltd, KenGen Ltd (tbc), Ministry of Education, Nakuru County och Narok County, befolkningen i framförallt Suswa and Rapland, Forum Syd, ILO och Sida (genom ambassaden i Nairobi). Det förutses att detta partnerskap kan bli en modell för replikering i andra län samt inom andra sektorer för att uppnå en inkluderande tillväxt i Kenya. Ministry of Education är en av de aktörer som uttryckt intresse att se PPDPn som en pilot för replikering och uppskalning.
Programmet sträcker sig över fyra år, inklusive en uppstartsfas (inception) på 12 månader. För att möta ovan nämnda utvecklingsbehov hos såväl befolkningen, företag och regeringsfunktioner i området, är det övergripande syftet med PPDPn att minska fattigdom och förbättra levnadsförhållanden genom skapandet av anständiga jobb (formella och informella), samt att stärka kapacitetet hos befolkningen att kräva sina rättigheter vad gäller gundläggande samhällstjänster. Detta kommer att uppnås genom tre huvudskliga delmål, (1) Anständiga jobb som ett resultat av förbättrade formella kunskaper och färdigheter genom yrkesutbildning, (2) Anständiga jobb, nya och växande företag som ett resultat av ökade kunskaper, affärsutveckling och tillgång till finansiering, samt (3) Befolkningen har kunskap och kapacitet att efterfråga publika samhällstjänster såsom vatten, utbildning, hälsa och sanitet. Programmet riktar sig till personer inom både den formella och den informella ekonomin, med ett särksilt fokus på unga och kvinnor/flickor.

The private company Akiira Geothermal Ltd is setting up a geothermal power plant in the southern region of the Rift Valley near Naivasha in Kenya. The current production of renewable energy is expected to contribute to Kenya's growing economy. In order for the adjoining pastoral communities to benefit from economic growth, conscious and proactive measures must be taken. Akiira is determined that their investment in the region should have a positive impact on the local communities in terms of local participation and job creation during the construction and operational phase. At the moment, it is difficult for Akiira to hire local labor, for other than simple jobs such as drivers, guards, etc., due to lack of education and other skills among the local population.
Due to the discrepancy between the private sector needs of employable labor and the local population's lack of matching knowledge and skills, Akiira Geothermal Ltd and Sida, represented by the Swedish Embassy in Nairobi, initiated a partnership to address some of the development challenges in the region, such as poverty, dismissal, lack of employability, gender inequality and lack of fundamental rights to public services. The model of the partnership is a Public Private Development Partnership (PPDP) with the International Labor Organization (ILO) as coordinator, implementer and agreement partner of the program. Forum Syd will also play a key role in the implementation of the program. In addition, a larger number of partners will also participate and contribute to the jointly set goals of the partnership. The closest involved partners to PPDP are Akiira Ltd, KenGen Ltd (tbc), the Ministry of Education, Nakuru County and Narok County, the population of, in particular, Suswa and Rapland, Forum South, ILO and Sida (through the Embassy of Sweden in Nairobi). It is envisaged that this partnership can be a model for replication in other counties as well as in other sectors to achieve inclusive growth in Kenya. The Ministry of Education is one of the partners who has expressed interest in seeing the PPDP as a pilot for replication and scaling.
The program extends over four years, including a start-up/inception phase of 12 months. In order to meet the above-mentioned developmental needs of the local population, businesses and governmental functions in the area, the overall purpose of PPDPs is to reduce poverty and improve living conditions through the creation of decent jobs (formal and informal) and to strengthen the capacity of the population to access their rights to public and social services. This will be achieved through three main goals, (1) Decent jobs as a result of improved formal skills and skills through vocational education, (2) Decent jobs, new and growing companies as a result of increased knowledge, business development and access to finance, and (3) The population has the knowledge and capacity to demand public and social services such as water, education, health and sanitation. The program is targeting people in both the formal and informal economy, with a particular focus on young people and women/girls.

participating-org.narrative: International Labour Organisation - Regular Budget Supplementary Account

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
4.3 - By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
4.3 - Senast 2030 säkerställa alla kvinnor och män lika tillgång till yrkesutbildning och eftergymnasial utbildning, inklusive högskoleutbildning, av god kvalitet till en överkomlig kostnad.
4.4 - By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.

4.4 - Till 2030 väsentligen öka det antal ungdomar och vuxna som har relevanta färdigheter, däribland tekniska färdigheter och yrkeskunnande, för sysselsättning, anständigt arbete och entreprenörskap.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.

title.narrative: Agreement PPDP inclusive growth through decent work
Decision PPDP inclusive growth through decent work in the great rift valley
Decision Amendment PPDP inclusive growth through decent work in the great rift valley

description.narrative: During its inception period, the project has drawn a lot of interest from public and private partners in Kenya due to its unique approach of Public-Private Development Partnership commonly referred to as PPDP. Focus and efforts were placed on re-engaging project partners’, coordination and project set up for the implementation phase and, mobilizing strategic partners to contribute towards the project. This included the introduction of the PPDP concept to partners and marketing the concept of a ‘win-win’ situation to key stakeholders. Key milestones during the re-engagement period included obtaining the strong support and commitment of key partners and stakeholders, the signing of MoUs on 22nd November 2018, by Nakuru and Narok counties, paving way for formal engagement with the counties during the project implementation period. The total mobilized resources during the inception period both financial and in- kind is a total of USD 2,329,849 and expected financial commitment discussion to be concluded going forward. The PPDP project will mobilize more partners in years 2, 3 and 4 to bridge the overall budget deficit and to stive toward a vision of a maximum 50% Sida funding. Strategies to be applied include the utilization of the communication strategy to communicate return on investment to private sector partners. The private sector engagement strategy will also be applied to mobilize more resources. In addition negotiations with the county governments are ongoing to revise their financial commitments upward. The governance structures of the project have been set up. The Partnership Steering Committee (PSC) with a mandate to approve recommendations proposed by the technical team was constituted. At the same time, the Partnership Advisory Committee, which provides technical guidance on project implementation was also constituted. The two committees provided guidance on communication and decision making structure of the partnership. In addition, the meetings resulted in a full understanding of the roles each partner will play in the project. There was a demonstration of project ownership from the two meetings based on the level of a committee member’s engagement with the PPDP project management team. Under PAC the project team constituted the Skills Technical Working Group Committee (STWG) & Sub-Committee which provided and will continue to provide technical assistance on skills development component and platform for dialogue and knowledge sharing between industry/private sector with County Government and learning institutions. Through partnership engagement, the PPDP project secured Industrial attachment for trainees and internships with KenGen PLC, Oserian Development Company Ltd and through NITA’s attachment framework. Under outcome 2, Decent jobs created from new and growing businesses, the project team through a study identified the current economic opportunities in Narok (Suswa) and Nakuru (Raplands) counties. Communities are engaged in small scale farming-, livestock keeping- tour guiding, curio, and beadwork. The Training needs assessment was carried out to identify the skills and income generation training, and post-training support activities and entrepreneurship support needed to create employment and business opportunities in the sectors identified. The PPDP jointly with the county governments, private sector, and Micro and Small Enterprises Authority identified 16 trainees. The identified 16 were trained as trainers in the ILO’s Start and Improve Your Business programme, a basic business management training programme with a focus on starting and improving small businesses as a strategy for creating more and better employment for women and men. All 16 ToTs developed action plans with targets of training at least a total of 400 entrepreneurs in year 2 of the PPDP project. Through Forum Syd efforts, Community mobilization meetings were used as a strategy in both Nakuru and Narok Counties. The village level project inception meetings reached out to a total of 1,450 community members through community barazas (village level meetings). As a result of these meetings, the target community and duty bearers are aware of the project deliverables, expected outcomes, the structure of the project as well as their expected role. This was demonstrated by the level of commitment to ensuring that the project has local ownership and buy-in. To increase the capacity of target communities to lobby for public service provision, the project employed the use of the Right(s) Way Forward Methodology (RWF). A TOT workshop was conducted and the trainers have a good understanding of the processes of the Right(s) Way Forward and have the confidence to facilitate the rollout of methodology in the community. The trained trainers applying the skills acquired from the training of trainers will organize 33 community level workshops for need identification towards development of the community action plans. The (PPDP) approach provides a unique model to leverage on various partners strengths towards a common development objective with the community at the center. This is evident by Partnerships engagements, private sector commitments, signing of MoUs between ILO and county governments and community empowerment initiatives during the inception period have drawn interests from Nyeri and Turkana County Governments to have them supported to implement the same model in their counties. In addition the project hosted high-level delegation of Team Sweden members The project also approached UNAIDS to identify areas of collaboration in addressing the HIV and AIDS challenges facing the affected communities. UNAIDS is supporting Narok County in the elimination of mother to Child transmission and has a programme in Nakuru on ending AIDS in cities. This partnership is not yet formalized but it is under discussion. Once concretized, the partnership will help in addressing HIV and AIDS as one of the project’s identified cross-cutting issues. The collaboration will also help the project to address sexual and reproductive health challenges as requested by Narok County Governor during the Memorandum of Understanding signing ceremony. The project commissioned a baseline survey to collect remaining baseline information to inform the monitoring and evaluation and results frameworks for the project. A gender study was also commissioned to facilitate full inclusion of women within the project area in the context of employability, entrepreneurship and livelihoods in Nakuru and Narok counties to better mainstream gender. Additionally, a communication expert was identified to help in the Development of Communication and Advocacy strategy for messaging, communicating results and impact of the project among targeted groups and stakeholders. In addition, during the inception period, the PPDP team conducted engagement meetings with the County governments of Nakuru and Narok to champion for the project support. An implementation agreement was signed between ILO and Forum Syd for component 3. The PPDP goal is aligned with promoting employment creation and employability, a priority jointly set by the government, employers and workers organizations, under the Kenya Decent Work Country Programme. The project is among the pathways through which the DWCP and the Decent Work agenda is being Implemented in the country. According to Agreement between Sida and the ILO, the ILO shall submit an annual technical progress report and a certified financial report, which is a combined financial report and audit report, according to ILO reporting format. The first reporting period covers 10 months of operations and constitutes an inception phase of the project, with specific deliverables to be achieved during the inception phase. An approval of the Inception report, hence the inception phase is a condition stipulated in the Agreement, regulating a second disbursement and hence the continuation of the program. Overall it is noted that the program implementation for the inception phase is lagging behind in terms of expected results. The overall scoring of the inception phase deliveries is hence classified as somewhat unsatisfactory. Initially in the draft version of the annual progress report, ILO and Forum Syd had put their own scoring on a satisfactory level but after the review meeting and after going through all the deliveries, the actual results and constraints, it was jointly agreed that the scoring should rather be unsatisfactory (see meeting minutes from review meeting 17th of April 2019, followed by meeting minutes from 2nd Review meeting on the 6th of May 2019). However, there are reasonable explanations to this unsatisfactory score which are explained in detail in the meeting minutes provided, dated 17th of April 2019. In general terms it has to do with delay in recruitment and sub-contracting, hence delay of inception phase implementation, but also due to governmental bureaucratic processes and legal constraints within the government structures. It was also somewhat underestimated from the implementing partners side how much time and effort the stakeholder engagements would really entail, hence delay in some of these deliveries as well. After the first review meeting on 17th of April 2019, the partners ILO and Forum Syd updated the reports and did the necessary revisions based on the comments from Sida provided in written as well as during the review meeting. A second review meeting was held 6th of May 2019 to discuss the revised reports and documents, see attached meeting minutes. Details about the discussions and comments from Sida are thoroughly described in attached meeting minutes. After the 2nd review meeting ILO and Forum Syd were to finalize the final versions of the Annual progress Report, Certified Financial report including annex, and project document including annexes. The mentioned final documents were partly submitted to Sida on the 9th of May and partly on the 15th of May. Sida spent substantial time with ILO and Forum Syd during the review stage for the inception phase to make sure that Theory of Change, Result Framework, partner contribution matrix and Budget were aligned and harmonized. This will substantially faciliate both implementation and reporting and follow up of the program going forward. Also, time and effort went into receiving adequate and detailed financial details from ILO regarding the certified financial statement, which in its firstly provided form was insufficient for Sida in order to make any proper follow up and to reassure the usage of Sida funds. Discussion and agreement on a budget template and financial reporting scheme for the future was discussed an agreed, in order to facilite qualitative and harmonized financial follow up and reporting going forward. On May 22nd 2019 Sida, through the Embassy of Sweden i Nairobi, via email correspondence approved the inception report and annexes including certified financial report for the inception phase. Hence Sida has approved of the results achieved during the implementation of the inception phase which was a condition in the agreement in order for the partner to request a 2nd disbursement and for the program to continue. Sida sees not reasons for why the program should not continue. Rather the opposite, Sida foresees an interesting future for the PPDP project now when the structure and foundation is set and both staff and partners are on board.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
